subject: RE: [junit] Re: writing a test case for a function which returns 	void
msgSnippet: thanks David ... From: David Roussel [mailto:dir@bjss.co.uk] Sent: Wednesday, August 15, 2001 9:42 AM To: junit@yahoogroups.com Subject: RE: [junit] Re:
messageBody:
thanks David

-----Original Message-----
From: David Roussel [mailto:dir@...]
Sent: Wednesday, August 15, 2001 9:42 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [junit] Re: writing a test case for a function which
returns void


Here's a simple example.

public class Accumulator {
int acc;

public int getValue() {
return acc;
}

public void add( int inc )
acc += inc;
}
}

public class TestAccumulator {
...

testAdd() {
Accumulator a = new Accumulator();
assertEquals( 0, a.getValue() );
a.add( 5 );
assertEquals( 5, a.getValue() );
a.add( 50 );
assertEquals( 55, a.getValue() );
}
}

-----Original Message-----
From: Tariq Qazi [mailto:tariq.qazi@...]

Subject: RE: [junit] Re: writing a test case for a function which
returns void


Thanks,
Can you give me an example as to how it could possibly be used.


-----Original Message-----
From: David Roussel [mailto:dir@...]
Sent: Wednesday, August 15, 2001 9:32 AM

Subject: RE: [junit] Re: writing a test case for a function which

Yes, you can assert that is has changed the state of the object is was
invoked on.
